solution.text:
Diameter of tennis ball \(=d_T\)
\(\Rightarrow\)Radius of tennis ball \(=r_T\)
Diameter of basketball \(=d_B\)
\(\Rightarrow\)Radius of basketball \(=r_B\)
It is given that, \(d_T=\frac13 d_B\)
\(\Rightarrow 2r_T=\frac13 \times 2r_B\)
\(\Rightarrow r_T=\frac13 r_B\)
Volume of tennis ball\(=\frac43 \pi r_T^3\)
Volume of basketball\(=\frac43 \pi r_B^3\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac{Volume\,of\,tennis\,ball}{Volume\,of\,basketball}=\frac{\frac43 \pi r_T^3}{\frac43 \pi r_B^3}\)
\(=\frac{r_T^3}{r_B^3}=\left(\frac{r_T}{r_B}\right)^3=\left(\frac13\right)^3=\frac1{27}\)

content.text: The diameter of a tennis ball is one-third the diameter of a basketball. What fraction of the volume of the basketball is the volume of the tennis ball?
